[[Distinguished Service Cross (Australia)|Distinguished Service Cross]] |laterwork= }} [[General (Australia)|General]] '''David John Hurley''' [[Companion of the Order of Australia|AC]], [[Distinguished Service Cross (Australia)|DSC]] (born 26 August 1953) is a senior officer in the [[Australian Army]], currently serving in the position of [[Chief of the Defence Force (Australia)|Chief of the Defence Force]] (CDF). Hurley succeeded Air Chief Marshal [[Angus Houston]] as CDF on 4 July 2011.{{Cite news |first=James |last=Massola |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=David Hurley is made new defence force chief as part of sweeping renewal of top brass |url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/defence/david-hurley-is-made-new-defence-force-chief-as-part-of-sweeping-renewal-of-top-brass/story-e6frg8yo-1226067082383 |work=The Australian |publisher=News Limited |date=1 June 2011 |accessdate=9 June 2011}} ==Personal== David Hurley was born in [[Wollongong, New South Wales|Wollongong]], [[New South Wales]], on 26 August 1953. He holds the academic qualifications of [[Bachelor of Arts]] and [[Graduate Diploma]] in Defence Studies. He is married to Linda and has three children. ==Career== Hurley graduated from the [[Royal Military College, Duntroon]] in December 1975 into the Royal Australian Infantry Corps. His initial posting was to the [[1st Battalion, Royal Australian Regiment]] (1RAR). Promoted [[Captain (Land)|Captain]] he was appointed Adjutant of the [[Sydney University Regiment]] before becoming Regimental Adjutant of the [[Royal Australian Regiment]]. He went on exchange to the 1st Battalion, [[Irish Guards]] (British Army) before serving with [[5th/7th Battalion, Royal Australian Regiment]] (5/7 RAR) and then being posted to [[Army Command and Staff College, Queenscliff]] in 1986. As a [[Major]] he was SO2 (Non-Corps Postings) in the Office of the Military Secretary (MS) befire being appointed Mechanised Infantry Adviser, Australian Army Project Team Malaysia in 1989. Promoted to [[Lieutenant Colonel]], he was posted as the Senior Career Adviser (Armour, Artillery, Engineers and Infantry) in the Office of the Military Secretary in 1990, appointed SO1 (Operations) Headquarters [[2nd Division (Australia)|2nd Division]] in early 1991 and in November 1991 assumed command of 1 RAR which he led during [[Operation Solace|Operation SOLACE]] (Somalia) in 1993. He was awarded the Distinguished Service Cross for this service. In 1994 he became SO1 (Operations), Headquarters [[1st Division (Australia)|1st Division]].[http://www.siaa.asn.au/simtect/2006/simkey.htm#hurley Defence Keynote Address - General David Hurley] Following promotion to [[Colonel]] he was appointed Chief of Staff, Headquarters 1st Division in June 1994, attended the [[U.S. Army War College]] between 1996 and 1997 and became Military Secretary to [[Chief of Army (Australia)|Chief of Army]] and then posted to Australian Defence Headquarters as Director of Preparedness and Mobilisation in December 1997.[http://www.aph.gov.au/house/committee/jfadt/dialog/dial_ap2.pdf List of Witnesses at Public Hearings] Canberra, 16 April 1998 As a [[Brigadier (Australia)|Brigadier]] he assumed command of the 1st Brigade in Darwin in January 1999 - During this period he oversaw the Brigade's transition to a higher degree of operational readiness and its support to Australian led operations in East Timor. He went on to be Director General Land Development within Capability Systems in January 2001. He was promoted [[Major General (Australia)|Major General]] in 2001 and served as Head Capability Systems Division from July 2001 and as [[Land Commander Australia]] from December 2002. Promoted to [[Lieutenant General (Australia)|Lieutenant General]] he assumed the new appointment of [[Chief of Capability Development Group]] in December 2003, went on to take the newly separated appointment of [[Chief of Joint Operations (Australia)|Chief of Joint Operations]] in September 2007 and became [[Vice Chief of the Defence Force (Australia)|Vice Chief of the Defence Force]] in July 2008.[http://www.kcl.ac.uk/newsevents/news/newsrecords/2010/Nov/GeneralSirJohnHackettCentenaryLectures.aspx Hackett Centenary Lectures] Kings College London, 12 November 2010 He took his present role, in the rank of [[General (Australia)|General]], as [[Chief of the Defence Force (Australia)|Chief of the Defence Force]] in July 2011. ==Honours and awards==
